item.title: Single Antibody Incubation Following Western Blotting
item.description:
Materials

Equipment & Devices‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Commercial Kits‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Containers & Consumables Amount Specifications Location
micropipettes and sterile pipette tips
pipetting aid and serological pipettes
Reagents & Solutions‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
bovine serum albumin BSAmilkpowder 1.25 g1.25 g for blocking buffer
for antibody dilution buffer
phosphate buffered saline PBS tris buffered saline TBS
phosphate buffered saline with Tween20 0.1 % PBST tris buffered saline with Tween20 0.1 % TBST
Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
horseradish peroxidase HRP conjugated antibody

Procedure

Preparations

  1. Prepare 25 mL of blocking buffer per membrane by dissolving 1.25 g1.25 g of BSAmilkpowder in 25 mL of PBSTTBST for a final concentration of 5 %0.05 g/mL.
  1. Prepare 25 mL of antibody dilution buffer per two membranes by mixing 1 mL of blocking buffer with 24 mL of PBSTTBST for a final BSAmilkpowder concentration of 0.002 g/mLmilkpowder.
  1. Add 1 ¬µL of the StrepMAB-Classic HRP conjugate antibody into the antibody dilution buffer.

Membrane Processing and Blocking

  1. Cut the membrane into pieces if different areas are to be stained with different antibodies and mark the pieces to always know their orientation, otherwise mark the whole membrane to always know it’s orientation.
  2. Place the nitrocellulose membrane into a tray on a tray shaker.
  3. Add 20 ml blocking buffer and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 1 h or @ 4 ¬∞C with gentle agitation overnight.
1:00:00
üîî
  1. Replace the blocking buffer with 10 mL PBSTTBST and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Replace the PBSTTBST and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Replace the PBSTTBST and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî

Antibody Binding

  1. Replace the PBSTTBST with 12.5 ml of the diluted antibody and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 1h or @ 4 ¬∞C with gentle agitation overnight.
1:00:00
üîî

Membrane Washing

  1. Replace the diluted antibody with 10 mL PBSTTBST and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Replace the PBSTTBST and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Replace the PBSTTBST with 10 mL PBSTBS and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Replace the PBSTBS and incubate @ RT with gentle agitation for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî

Procedure

General remark
‚ö†Ô∏è Ponceau S staining needs to be done prior to antibody incubation.

Heading 1

  1. Prepare a plastic tray with dsH2O on a tray shaker.
  2. Place the nitrocellulose membrane into the dsH2O and gently agitate for 2 minutes.
0:02:00
üîî
  1. Change the dsH2O and gently agitate for 2 minutes.
0:02:00
üîî
  1. Replace the dsH2O with approximately 50 mL of Ponceau S solution and gently agitate for 5 minutes or until protein bands become visible.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Transfer the Ponceau S solution into a sterile 50 mL falcon tube for reuse.
  2. Add fresh dsH2O to the nitrocellulose membrane and gently agitate for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Change the dsH2O and gently agitate for 5 minutes or until background is sufficiently reduced.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Take an epilumination picture at an appropriate imager.
Time Remark
‚ö†Ô∏è Image immediately as Ponceau S fades quickly over time.
  1. Replace the dsH2O in the tray with PBST TBST.
  1. Place the nitrocellulose membrane into the PBST TBST and gently agitate for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Change the PBST TBST and gently agitate for 5 minutes or until the nitrocellulose membrane appears completely white again.

0:10:00

Procedure

Heading 1

  1. Prepare the developing solution consisting of stable peroxide and luminol/enhancer 200 ¬µL each.
  2. Add the membrane to a transparent plastic wrap and remove all liquid with absorbing paper or by closing and opening the plastic and removing the liquid on the plastic.
  3. Pipette 400¬µl developing solution onto the membrane and close the plastic to ensure equal distribution.
  4. Incubate the developing solution on the membrane for 5 minutes.

item.title: Coomassie Brilliant Blue Staining Following SDS-PAGE
item.description:
Materials

Equipment & Devices‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
tray shaker
cold room
Commercial Kits‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Containers & Consumables Amount Specifications Location
plastic container 1-2/gel for incubation with staining and destaining solutions
sterile falcon tube 50 mL 1-2/gel for storage of used staining and destaining solutions
Reagents & Solutions‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Coomassie brilliant blue staining solution 50 mL e.g. RotiBlue quick
destaining solution (ethanol EtOH 30 %) ~200 mL
dsH2O
Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
SDS-PAGE gel with protein samples

Procedure

General Remark
‚ö†Ô∏è In general, staining a gel is not recommended when downstream processing, such as western blotting, is required, as it can reduce blotting efficiency.

Heading 1

  1. Place the gel into approximately 50 mL of Coomassie stain, such as ROTI¬ÆBlue quick.
  2. Incubate the gel @ RT for 1 h or overnight @ 4 ¬∞C.
Staining Duration

‚ö†Ô∏è You may check the gel after 15, 30, and 45 minutes and stop the incubation once the desired band intensity is achieved. Note that overnight incubation often reveals additional bands not visible after 1 hour. However, some Coomassie stains are not suitable for overnight incubation. ROTI¬ÆBlue Quick does not overstain and can be used for overnight incubation. Refer to the corresponding manufacturer’s manual for further information.

item.title: Imaging following agarose gel electrophoresis (AGE)
item.description:
imaging in general, but add that lanes with samples for gel extraction need to be cut off prior to imaging.

Subsequent Purification
‚ö†Ô∏è For downstream purification, cut away all lanes with samples that are intended for later gel extraction. UV light is mutagenic and can damage or alter DNA, so the band intended for purification should not be exposed to UV light. Instead, determine its position by imaging only the well containing the corresponding sample intended for UV imaging.

item.title: Western Blotting
item.description:
Materials

Equipment & Devices‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
cold room @ 4 ¬∞C
Commercial Kits‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
blotting cell
BIO-RAD Trans-Blot¬Æ Electrophoretic Transfer Cell manual		 1/2-4 gels electrode chamber
gel holder cassette
blotting sponges
power source
BIO-RAD PowerPack‚Ñ¢ 1000 manual
Containers & Consumables Amount Specifications Location
small magnetic stir bar 1/2-4 gels
filter paper (Whatman paper) 2/gel
nitrocellulose membrane 1/gel default: 0.45¬µm
plastic trays 2/gel
Reagents & Solutions‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
ethanol EtOH 30 % ~200 mL/gel for destaining coomassie stained gels
dsH2O ~200 mL/gel for equilibrating the nitrocellulose membrane
tris-glycine(-SDS)-MeOH Towbin transfer buffer ~2500 mL
ponceau S
Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
separating gel with protein samples

Procedure

Preparations the Day Before

  1. If the SDS-PAGE gel was previously stained with a Coomassie stain, such as Roti¬ÆBlue quick, destain in EtOH 30 % @ RT for 30 minutes or @ 4 ¬∞C overnight.
0:30:00
üîî
  1. Prepare 2.5l of transfer buffer by mixing 1750 mL of dsH2O with 500 mL of MeOH and 250 mL of 10x Western Blot tris-glycine(-SDS) Towbin transfer buffer.
  2. Let the transfer buffer cool down to 4 ¬∞C overnight.

Pre-Transfer Preparations

  1. Prepare a small tray with transfer buffer to fit the gel.
  2. Prepare a small tray with dsH2O to fit the nitrocellulose membrane.
  3. Place the SDS-PAGE gel into the tray with transfer buffer.

‚ö†Ô∏è Some Coomassie stains, such as Roti¬ÆBlue quick, tend to bind SDS, so the gel needs to be equilibrated in transfer buffer containing of at least 0.1 % SDS for 15 minutes.

item.title: Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE)
item.description:
Acrylamide
‚ÄºÔ∏è Acrylamide is toxic and must be handled exclusively in a chemical fume hood. Although gas-stabilized material reduces user exposure, it may still release hazardous gases. Therefore, all handling, preparation, and use must be performed under a chemical fume hood with appropriate personal protective equipment.

Procedure

Build the Chamber

  1. Degrease glass plates with EtOH 70%.
  2. Dry glass plates.
  3. Construct the gel cassette by bring together two glass plates with one black spacer at each of the short ends and fixing the plates and spacers with grey clamps so the long edges of the plates are even with each other and the spacers.
  4. Insert gel cassette into the casting stand and fix secure them with the black screws.
  5. Use dsH2O to test for leaks.
  6. Optionally, remove the dsH2O with paper towels.

Separating Gel

  1. Prepare the separating gel and the collecting gel (TEMED and APS catalyze the polymerization).
Gel Polymerization
‚ö†Ô∏è Both gels may be prepared in advance. However, TEMED and APS must only be added immediately before use, as their addition initiates polymerization.
  1. Finish preparing the separating gel by adding TEMED and APS.
‚ö†Ô∏è Use immediately.
  1. Pipette the appropriate volume (11 mL) of separating gel between the glass plates.
‚ö†Ô∏è Ensure sufficient space at the top of the gel to accommodate the well comb, leaving a gap of approximately 0.5‚Äì1 cm between the comb and the gel surface.
  1. Add 1 mL isopropanol (= 2-propanol) on top of the separating gel to displace bubbles and achieve an even surface.
  2. Let the gel polymerize @ RT for at least 30‚Äì45 minutes.
0:30:00
üîî
0:45:00
üîî

Collecting Gel

  1. Wash away the isopropanol with dsH2O.
  2. Insert the well comb between the glass plates.
  3. Finish preparing the collecting gel by adding TEMED and APS.
‚ö†Ô∏è Use immediately.
  1. Fill the collecting gel on top of the separating gel to the brim (surface needs to be even and free of bubbles).
  2. Let the gel polymerize @ RT for 30‚Äì45 minutes.
0:30:00
üîî
0:45:00
üîî
Gel Storage
  1. For gel storage, leave the combs in place, wrap the top with **dsH2O-moistened paper towels, and then seal with cling film to prevent drying.
  2. Store @ 4 ¬∞C for up to a week.

BSA Standard Preparation

Concentration Linearity
‚ö†Ô∏è Depending on the method, quantification of protein samples is only linear in the range of 100 to 2000 ng per band. BSA samples cover this concentration range.
  1. Prepare serial dilution of BSA with 750 ng/¬µL, 375 ng/¬µL, 187.5 ng/¬µL, 93.75 ng/¬µL, 46.875 ng/¬µL and 23.4375.
  2. Prepare a Stock of SDS-PAGE Sample-Buffer + DTT (refer to calculator below)
Reagent Volume Concentration c1 Concentration c2
SDS-PAGE Sample Buffer 10 ¬µL 2x
DTT 2 ¬µL 1 M 100 mM
dsH2O 5 ¬µL
= 17 ¬µL
  1. Prepare the BSA samples.
Reagent Volume Concentration c1 Concentration c2
mastermix 17 ¬µL
BSA sample 3 ¬µl
= 20 ¬µL

Sample Preparation

Concentration Linearity
‚ö†Ô∏è Depending on the method, quantification of protein samples is only linear in the range of 100 to 2000 ng per band. Sample quantity per band should be in the range covered by the BSA standard to allow for somewhat accurate quantification. Cell lysates can contain up to 20 ¬µg of proteins.
  1. Prepare a Stock of SDS-PAGE Sample-Buffer + DTT (refer to calculator below).

Running the Gel

  1. Carefully remove the well comb.
  2. Add cathode buffer on top of the gel.
  3. Pour out cathode buffer.
  4. Add cathode buffer on top of the gel.
  5. Add 10 ¬µL protein ladder in the first and last pocket.
  6. Add 20 ¬µL prepared sample per pocket.
  7. Document the loading scheme.
  8. Add electrophoresis chamber top on top of the glass plates.
  9. Remove the black screws from the casting stand and fix electrophoresis chamber top to the gel cassette with the black screws.
  10. Add approximately 2500 mL of the running buffer into the electrophoresis tank.
  11. Position the electrophoresis chamber in the electrophoresis tank.
  1. Fill the electrophoresis chamber with approximately 500 mL of cathode buffer until the electrodes are submerged but pay attention to the maximum filling marks.
  2. Run the gel @ 120V for approximately 40 minutes or until the samples are in the collecting gel.
0:40:00

  1. Increase the power to 175V for approximately 1h or until the bromphenole blue reaches the end of the gel.

item.title: Agarose Gel Electrophoresis (AGE)
item.description:
‚ö†Ô∏è Each Sample must have a concentration of at least 20 ng/¬µL, as 20 ng is the least amount that can be detected using EtBr.
‚ÄºÔ∏è EtBr is a carcinogen and can migrate through normal nitril gloves. If possible use an alternative ike Roti GelStain. If no alternative is available use specially for EtBr approved gloves.
‚ùóÔ∏è DNA intercalators such as Roti GelStain are still carcinogenic, but do not migrate throu normal nitril gloves.

Materials

Equipment & Devices Amount Specifications ¬†Location
power source manual
casting tray
well comb
electrophoresis chamber
Commercial Kits‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications ¬†Location
Containers & Consumables Amount Specifications ¬†Location
micropipettes and sterile pipette tips
Reaction Tube 1.5 ml 1/gel
1/sample		 for mastermix preparation
for sample preparation
Reagents & Solutions‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications ¬†Location
agarose default 0.35 g/50 mL gel solid
Tris-acetat-EDTA (TAE) buffer ~150 mL/gel 50 mL for gel
~100 mL as electrophoresis buffer
gel stain
ethidium bromide
Roti GelStain
0.2‚Äì0.5¬µg/mL (1‚Äì2.5 ¬µL/gel)
1 ¬µL/gel
stock 10mg/mL
ready-to-use
dsH2O see mastermix calculator below for sample dilution/for mastermix preparation
DNA loading buffer 5x see mastermix calculator below for sample preparation/for mastermix preparation
DNA ladder
HyperLadder 1kb
usually 10 ¬µL/gel
5 ¬µL/well (first and last well)
Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications ¬†Location
DNA sample at least 10 ng/well

Procedure:

Preparing the gel:

  1. Weigh the correct amount of agarose:

Hyperladder 1kb:

range of effective separation [bp] agarose gel percentage [%] agarose per gel [g/50mL]
2,000‚Äì50,000 0.5 0.25
1,000‚Äì20,000 0.6 0.30
800‚Äì12,000 0.7 0.35
800‚Äì10,000 (default) 0.8 0.40
600‚Äì10,000 0.9 0.45
400‚Äì8,000 1.0 0.50
300‚Äì7,000 1.2 0.60
200‚Äì3,000 1.5 0.75
100‚Äì2,000 2.0 1.00
25‚Äì1,000 3.0 1.50
10-500 4.0 2.00
10-300 5.0 2.50
  1. Add 50 mL of TAE buffer.
  2. Place in microwave and heat in bursts with swaying in between until boiling and until clear.
  3. Let cool down to approximately 50¬∞C in a water bath or under running water until only warm to touch.
  4. Add gel stain.
  • The standard concentration of ethidium bromide is 0.2¬µg/mL to 0.5¬µg/mL, which amounts to 1¬µL to 2.5¬µL per 50mL gel for a stock concentration of 10mg/mL.
‚ÄºÔ∏è EtBr is a carcinogen and can migrate through normal nitril gloves. If possible use an alternative ike Roti GelStain. If no alternative is available use specially for EtBr approved gloves.
  • The standard amount of Roti GelStain is 1¬µL per 50mL gel.
‚ùóÔ∏è DNA intercalators, such as Roti GelStain, are still carcinogenic, but do not migrate throu normal nitril gloves.

Casting the Gel:

  1. Place the casting tray into the gel chamber rotated 90¬∞ to prevent the gel from running in the chamber.
  2. Place the well comb.
  3. Pour in the gel from a corner on the opposite site from the well comb.
  4. Remove all bubbles, especially near the comb or where the DNA will be running, if necessary.
  5. Let the gel solidify for approximately 30 minutes.

Preparing the DNA:

‚ÑπÔ∏è Prepare a mastermix when doing multiple samples with similar DNA concentration containing dsH2O and DNA loading buffer 5x. Use number of samples plus at least one for the mastermix volume multiplyer.

item.title: Bacterial Plasmid Preparation Culture
item.description:
Materials

Equipment & Devices‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
laminar airflow workbench
shaker incubator
photometer for measuring OD600
Commercial Kits‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Containers & Consumables Amount Specifications Location
micropipettes and sterile pipette tips
pipetting aid and serological pipette
photometer cuvette 1/culture
liquid culture tubes or sterile falcon tubes 15 mL 1/culture
sterile reaction tube 1 for antibiotic aliquot
Reagents & Solutions‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
Luria-Bertani liquid medium 6 mL/culture
suitable antibiotic stock solution, tpically 1000x
Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
LB agar plate with transformed bacteria 1/plasmid

Procedure

Preparation

  1. Transform a suitable strain of bacteria and plate transformed bacteria on a LB-agar Plate containing appropriate selection markers (Antibiotic, X-Gal).
  2. Prepare 6 mL of sterile LB medium per clone.

Culture

‚ö†Ô∏è To reduce risk of contamination, all subsequent steps can be carried out under laminar airflow.
  1. Transfer 1 mL of the 6 mL LB medium into a photometer cuvette for the zero value.
  2. Transfer 5 mL of LB medium into the sterile 15 mL falcon tube or liquid culturing tube.
  3. Supplement the 5 mL of LB medium with a suitable antibiotic.
‚ùóÔ∏è To minimize exposure to microorganisms, all subsequent steps should be carried out under laminar airflow.
  1. Pick a suitable clone with a pipette tip.
  2. Optionally streak pipette tip over fresh plate as a backup.
  3. Drop the pipette tip into the prepared medium.
  4. Incubate the culture @ 37 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for approximately 2‚Äì4 h until an OD600 ~ 0.4‚Äì0.8 (best 0.6) is reached.
Incubation @ 30 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm overnight is also possible.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî
  1. Document the start time and refer to BiochemProtocols bacterial growth calculator.

Procede with Suitable Protocol

  • NucleoSpin¬Æ Plasmid Preparation

Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications Location
LB agar plate with transformed bacteria 1/plasmid

Procedure

Preparation

  1. Transform a suitable strain of bacteria and plate transformed bacteria on a LB-agar Plate containing appropriate selection markers (Antibiotic, X-Gal).
  2. Prepare 6 mL of sterile LB medium per clone.
  3. Prepare additional 500 mL of sterile LB medium in a 1 L Erlenmeyer flask per clone.
‚ö†Ô∏è Adjust volume as needed. The Erlenmeyer flask should be able to hold at least double the volume of LB medium used to allow for sufficient aeration.

Pre-Culture

‚ö†Ô∏è To reduce risk of contamination, all subsequent steps can be carried out under laminar airflow.
  1. Transfer 1 mL of the 6 mL LB medium into a photometer cuvette for the zero value.
  2. Transfer 5 mL of LB medium into the sterile 15 mL falcon tube or liquid culturing tube.
  3. Supplement the 5 mL of LB medium with a suitable antibiotic.
‚ùóÔ∏è To minimize exposure to microorganisms, all subsequent steps should be carried out under laminar airflow.
  1. Pick a suitable clone with a pipette tip.
  2. Optionally streak pipette tip over fresh plate as a backup.
  3. Drop the pipette tip into the prepared medium.
  4. Incubate the culture @ 37 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for approximately 2‚Äì4 h until an OD600 ~ 0.4‚Äì0.8 (best 0.6) is reached.
Incubation @ 30 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm overnight is also possible.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî
  1. Document the start time and refer to BiochemProtocols bacterial growth calculator.
  1. Measure the OD600 after 120 minutes and then every 60 minutes and until an OD600 of approximately 2.000 is reached.

Expression Culture

  1. Transfer 1 mL of the 500 mL LB medium into a photometer cuvette for the zero value.
  2. Supplement the 500 mL LB-medium with suitable antibiotic.
  3. Inoculate the 500 mL LB-medium with the pre-culture.
  4. Incubate batch @ 37 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for approximately 2‚Äì4 h until an OD600 of 0.4 to 0.8 (best 0.6) is reached.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî
  1. Take a 1 mL aliquot prior to induction, pellet and resuspend in 50 ¬µL PBS and 50 ¬µL 2x SDS-Page sample buffer for later SDS-PAGE analysis.
  2. Induce expression according to plasmid instructions.
Typical Induction Chemicals
Anhydrotetracycline AHT to a final concentration of 0.2 ¬µg/mL (50 ¬µL of a 2 mg/mL stock). Isopropyl-Œ≤-D-thiogalactopyranosid IPTG to a final concentration of 0.5 mM (250 ¬µL of a 1 M stock).
  1. Incubate @ 30 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for 2‚Äì4 h for expression of the protein.
‚ö†Ô∏è Incubation @ 25 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm overnight is also possible and may yield higher protein quantity and less protein aggregates. The final expression time and OD600 can be documented once when starting the harvest.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî
  1. Document the start time and refer to BiochemProtocols bacterial growth calculator.
  1. Measure the OD600 after 120 minutes and then every 60 minutes and until an OD600 of approximately 2.000 is reached.
Bacterial Growth Phases
‚ö†Ô∏è Cells should be harvested at the end of the logarithmic growth phase, typically at an OD600 of approximately 2.000, and before stationary phase is reached at an OD600 of 2.500‚Äì4.000.

Preparations 1 h before Harvesting

  1. Pre-cool a centrifuge to 4 ¬∞C for harvesting @ 3000‚Äì6000 g.

Procedure

Selecting a suitable Strain

Strain Application Features
E. coli DH5Œ± medium-yield plasmid DNA expression
(with blue/white screening)

(with blue/white screening)

with blue/white screening

T7 Inhibitor

for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase

T7 Inhibitor

for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase
E. coli C43(DE3) toxic membrane protein expression lacUV5 promoter
for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase

Preparations

  1. Thaw a one-shot of competent bacteria per transformation on ice for approximately 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Thaw the Plasmid on ice.
  2. Pre-warm 1000 ¬µL of LB medium per transformation to 37 ¬∞C.

Transformation

  1. Add 1‚Äì10 ng (up to 100-200 ng for difficult dransformations) of plasmid DNA to a one shot of 50‚Äì100 ¬µL of competent cells.
  2. Mix the bacteria by flicking or gentle stirring.
  3. Incubate transformation mix on ice for 30 minutes.
0:30:00
üîî
  1. Pre-heat a heating block or water bath to 42 ¬∞C.
  2. Incubate transformation mix in a heating block or water bath @ 42 ¬∞C for 45 to 60 seconds.
0:01:00
üîî
  1. Incubate transformation mix on ice for 5 minutes.
0:05:00
üîî
  1. Add 900 ¬µL LB medium to the transformation mix.
  2. Incubate transformation mix on a heating block @ 37 ¬∞C and @ 250 rpm for 1 h.
1:00:00
üîî

Plate Preparation

  1. Take two LB-agar Plates containing the appropriate antibiotic out of the fridge and let them warm up to RT.
  2. For blue/white selection plate 20 ¬µL of X-Gal on the Plates and let dry before plating any bacteria.

Plating

  1. Plate 100 ¬µL of the 1000 ŒºL bacterial suspension on one of the LB agar Plate.
  2. Centrifuge the residual 900 ¬µL @ 11,000 g for 30 s.
0:00:30
üîî
  1. Discard the supernatant.
  2. Remove residual supernatant with a 100 ¬µL pipette.
  3. Resuspend the bacteria pellet in 100 ¬µL LB medium.
  4. Plate the 100 ¬µL on the second LB agar Plate.
  5. Incubate the plates at 37 ¬∞C overnight or for blue/white selection for up to 48 h.
‚ÑπÔ∏è Plates can be stored @ 4¬∞C for up to four weeks.

Biological Materials‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä Amount Specifications ¬†Location
one-shot of suitable competent bacteria 1/strain

Procedure

Selecting a suitable Strain

Strain Application Features
E. coli DH5Œ± medium-yield plasmid DNA expression
(with blue/white screening)
E. coli TOP10 high-yield plasmid DNA expression
(with blue/white screening)
E. coli XL1blue plasmid DNA expression
with blue/white screening
E. coli BL21(DE3) protein expression lacUV5 promoter
for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase
E. coli BL21(DE3) pLysS (toxic) protein expression T7 Inhibitor
E. coli Rosetta(DE3) (eucaryotic) protein expression lacUV5 promoter
for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase
E. coli C41(DE3) toxic protein expression lacUV5 promoter
for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase
E. coli C43(DE3) toxic membrane protein expression lacUV5 promoter
for IPTG induced expression of t-RNA polymerase

Preparations

  1. Prepare one LB-agar Plate without any antibiotics.
  2. Prepare 110 mL of LB medium.

Plating Bacteria

  1. Choose a desired strain of Escherichia coli cells.
  2. Plate a one shot directly on a LB-agar Plate.
  3. Let the bacteria grow over night @ 37 ¬∞C.

Pre-culture

  1. Transfer 1 mL of the 110 mL LB medium into a photometer cuvette for the zero value.
  2. Transfer 5 mL of the 109 mL LB medium into a sterile 15 mL falcon tube.
  3. Pick a suitable clone with pipette tip.
  4. Drop pipette tip into the 5 mL of LB medium.
  5. Incubate pre-culture @ 37 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for approximately 2‚Äì4 h until an OD600 ~ 0.4‚Äì0.8 (best 0.6) is reached or incubate @ 30 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm overnight.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî

Main-culture

  1. Transfer 1 mL of the 104 mL LB medium into a photometer cuvette for the zero value.
  2. Transfer 100 mL LB-medium into a sterile 200 mL Erlenmeyer flask.
  3. Inoculate the 100 mL LB-medium with the pre-culture.
  4. Incubate batch @ 37 ¬∞C and shaking @ 250 rpm for approximately 2‚Äì4 h until an OD600 of 0.4 to 0.8 (best 0.6) is reached.
2:00:00
üîî
3:00:00
üîî
4:00:00
üîî

Preparations Before Harvesting

  1. Prepare 50 mL of Inoue transformation buffer from your 10x stock or by supplementing 50mL of PIPES (or alternatively MOPES) buffer 10 mM (pH 6.8 with acetic acid) with MnCl2 55 mM, CaCl2 15 mM and KCl 250 mM and cool on ice until further use.
  2. Prepare 10 mL of Inoue storage buffer by supplementing 8 mL of Inoue transformation buffer with 750 ¬µL of DMSO (7.5 %) and 1250 ¬µL of Glycerol 85% (10.625 %) and cool on ice until further use.
  3. Pre-cool 80 x sterile 1.5 mL reaction tubes.
  4. Pre-cool a centrifuge to 4 ¬∞C for harvesting @ 3000‚Äì6000 g.

Cell harvesting

  1. Transfer the 100 mL of culture into 2 x sterile 50 mL falcon tubes.
  2. Harvest cells by centrifugation @ 3000‚Äì6000 g and @ 4 ¬∞C for 10 minutes.
0:10:00
üîî
  1. Discard the medium and let pellet dry overhead on paper towels for 2 minutes.
0:02:00
üîî

Generating Competency

  1. Resuspend the pellet in 16 mL of ice-cold Inoue transformation buffer each by rotating end-over-end.
  2. Harvest cells by centrifugation @ 3000‚Äì6000 g and @ 4 ¬∞C for 10 minutes.
0:10:00
üîî
  1. Discard the medium and let pellet dry overhead on paper towels for 2 minutes.
0:02:00
üîî

Storage

  1. Resuspend the pellet in 4 mL of ice-cold Inoue storage buffer each by rotating end-over-end for 10 minutes.
0:10:00
üîî
  1. Prepare some liquid nitrogen.
  2. Aliquot the cells in 100 ¬µL fractions in the pre-cooled sterile 1.5 mL reaction tubes.
  3. Immediately freeze aliquots in liquid nitrogen.
  4. Store the one shots at ‚Äì60 ¬∞C.
‚ö†Ô∏è Cells from here on are extremely sensitive to temperature increases.

Proceed with Suitable Protocol

item.description:

Procedure

Preparations

  1. Prepare and pre-cool 10 mL Tris-HCl-NaCl-MgCl2 bacterial lysis buffer as a equibrilation and wash buffer per 5 mL bacterial lysate from 500 mL bacterial culture volume (or 10 mL buffer W).
  2. Prepare and pre-cool 1 mL biotin elution buffer per 5 mL bacterial lysate from 500 mL bacterial culture volume (or 1 mL buffer BXT).

Equilibrating the Column

  1. Place the column onto a stand in the cold room @ 2-8 ¬∞C.
  2. Remove the top cap.
‚ö†Ô∏è Keep the top cap for resealing and reuse.
  1. Twist of bottom cap.
  2. Let the storage buffer flow through.
  3. Equilibrate the column with 1 column bed volume (200 ¬µL) of wash buffer (or buffer W).
  4. Equilibrate the column with 1 column bed volume (200 ¬µL) of wash buffer (or buffer W).

First Binding the Protein and Washing

  1. Add 0.5-12.5 column bed volume (100 to 2500 ¬µL) of sample onto the column and let the sample flow through completely.
Binding

Binding usually takes 20-30 minutes per 2 mL, but can take up to 1h in some cases.
